See link{" "} https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-deploy-react-router-based-app-to-netlify/
with SPA , once I refresh any the route page url (Not index main page url), I get a page not found error.
This is because when we access any route on our local machine, React Router handles the routing.
But when we deploy the application on any server, directly accessing the route will send the request to the server itself (Netlify in our case).
  • Create a new file with the name _redirects
  • Place the file under public folder of the project
  • add the following contents inside it /* /index.html 200
  • Here, we're telling Netlify to redirect all the routes to the index.html file.
  • The index.html file contains our entire React app code
  • And as routing is handled by our React app which is contained in the index.html file, our application will work without a page not found issue.
); }; export default O1_DeployNetlify;

import { Anchor, Answer, IMG, MainChildArea, Question } from "../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, SpanGreen, SpanRed, SpanSky, SpanTeal } from "../../../../components/Highlight"; import Li from "../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; import ULdisc from "../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; import docker_1 from "../../../../assets/docker_1.jpg"; const O1_WhatIsDocker = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
From course on udemy{" "} {" "}
part of course{" "}
What is Docker? üëå ‚Äî Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers.
üëå ‚Äî Docker solves several classic developer problems that have been around for decades. Here‚Äôs a breakdown:
{" "}
üîë 1. ‚ÄúIt works on my machine‚Äù problem
  • The issue: An app works on a developer‚Äôs laptop but fails on a teammate‚Äôs laptop, a test server, or in production. (Because of Differences in OS, JDK versions, libraries, or system configuration.){" "}
  • Docker solution: The app runs in a container with everything it needs (JDK, libs, configs) ‚Üí always the same, no matter where you run it.
    • üîë 2. Dependency hell
  • The issue: Different projects need different versions of the same library or runtime (e.g., Java 8 vs Java 21, Python 2 vs 3). Installing them all on one machine causes conflicts.
  • Docker solution: Each app runs in its own isolated container with its own dependencies ‚Üí no conflicts.
    • üîë 3. Environment setup pain
  • The issue: Setting up a dev/test environment can take hours (install DB, configure JDK, set up queues, etc.).
  • Docker solution: You just run docker run ... or docker-compose up ‚Üí instant, reproducible environment.
    • üîë 4. Portability across OS & infrastructure
  • The issue: An app may behave differently on Windows vs Linux, or local vs cloud servers.
  • Docker solution: Containers are portable ‚Äî run the same on any OS that supports Docker.
    • üîë 5. Scaling and resource efficiency
  • The issue: Virtual machines (VMs) are heavy, slow to start, and consume lots of resources.
  • Docker solution: Containers are lightweight (share the host kernel) and start in seconds ‚Üí efficient for microservices and cloud.
    • üîë 6. CI/CD & DevOps automation
  • The issue: Moving code from dev ‚Üí test ‚Üí prod often requires custom scripts and manual steps.
  • Docker solution: The Docker image is the artifact. The same image is deployed everywhere, which simplifies CI/CD pipelines.
    • ‚úÖ In short:
    Docker makes development, testing, and deployment faster, more consistent, and less painful by standardizing environments.


    Docker does not use your host's JDK ‚Äî it downloads and uses the one I specify in the image.
    That's why the app behaves the same across different machines and OSs. issues. ‚úÖ That means no more{" "} ‚Äúbut it worked on my machine‚Äù.

    So ,when I run the container:
  • üëâ It doesn‚Äôt matter if your host machine has JDK 8, 21, or none at all.
  • üëâ The container always has JDK 21 inside.
  • Meaning , when Idockerize Spring Boot app, the Docker image will include (download) the JDK version I specified.
    • Docker core concepts
    When saying dockerize a Spring boot app we mean we doing the following things.
  • Docker File
    Docker file is a text file that contains a set of instructions for building a Docker image. We write a Dockerfile that describes how to build your app image:
  • what operating system to start from.
  • what software packages to install.
  • what files to copy in.
  • and what command to run when the container starts.
  • Docker Image
    Docker Image defines everything my application needs to run inside a container.
    Think of it like a class definition in programming ‚Äî it defines what the object (container) will look like.
  • A blueprint/template for creating containers.
  • Built from a Dockerfile.
  • Read-only (cannot be changed once built).
  • Can be stored and shared (e.g., on Docker Hub).
  • Docker Container
    Think of it like an object created from a class ‚Äî you can have many containers (objects) from one image (class).
  • A running instance of a Docker image.
  • Writable layer on top of the image (so it can store logs, temp files, etc.).
  • You can run multiple containers from the same image.
  • Containers can start, stop, restart, and be deleted.
    •
    ); }; export default O1_WhatIsDocker;

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../components"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; import Li from "../../../../components/ui/Li"; import { DivDoubleBorder, SpanBlue, SpanGreen, SpanRed, SpanSky } from "../../../../components/Highlight"; const O3_InstallWSL2 = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
Docker needs a Linux kernel In order to run, because it was designed for Linux containers (using cgroups, namespaces, etc.).
Windows itself doesn‚Äôt have a native Linux kernel.
WSL2 provides a real Linux kernel inside Windows ‚Üí which lets Docker run Linux containers natively.
Docker can run on Windows 11 through WSL2.
Hence, we need to install WSL2.
What is WSL2
WSL2 ( Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 ) is a feature in Windows 10/11 that lets you run a real Linux environment inside Windows, without needing a separate virtual machine or dual-boot.
It's basically Linux running inside Windows ‚Äî but in a lightweight, integrated way.

‚úÖ In short:

WSL2 = A real Linux kernel running inside Windows ‚Üí so you can use Linux apps and tools as if you were on a Linux machine.

üîπWhat you can do with WSL2?
  • Install a Linux distribution (Ubuntu, Debian, etc.) from the Microsoft Store.
  • Run Linux commands and tools (e.g., apt, grep, ssh, vim) directly in Windows.
  • Run Linux-based apps like Docker, Kafka, PostgreSQL, Redis, etc.
  • Access Linux files from Windows (\\wsl$\Ubuntu\home\...).
  • Access Windows files from Linux (/mnt/c/Users/...).
    •
    üîπWhy developers use WSL2?
  • Docker & Containers ‚Üí Needs a Linux kernel ‚Üí WSL2 provides it.
  • Run Linux tools natively ‚Üí No need for a separate VM.
  • Lightweight & fast ‚Üí Uses fewer resources than VirtualBox/VMware.
  • Tight Windows integration ‚Üí You can mix Windows + Linux workflows easily.
    • ); }; export default O3_InstallWSL2;

import { Anchor, IMG, MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, SpanBlue, SpanGreen, SpanRed } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; import kafka_1 from "../../../../../assets/kafka_1.jpg"; import kafka_2 from "../../../../../assets/kafka_2.jpg"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; const O1_Introduction = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
From course on udemy{" "} {" "} part of course{" "}
See Kafka relevent data and docs from link of:
  • See link from Baeldung
  • See link from geeksforgeeks{" "}
    • Kafka Ecosystem
    Kafka is a distibuted system, and it acts as a cluster.
    Kafka consists of a set of brokers. A Cluster has minimum of 3brokers.
    1. Kafka Broker
    The Broker is the Kafka Server. A Kafka broker is like a single worker or machine in the Kafka system. Its main jobs are
  • to receive new messages coming in safely
  • store those messages and provide the stored messages to any consumers that need them
    •  The broker acts as the middle person between producers sending messages and consumers receiving messages
    2. Cluster
    A Kafka cluster is a group of multiple Kafka brokers all working together. A Cluster has minimum of 3 brokers.
    Having a cluster allows Kafka to handle very large amounts of data. If more data needs to be processed new brokers can easily be added to make the cluster bigger. If less data needs processing, brokers can be removed to make the cluster smaller.
    3. Topic
    A topic is like a labelled box or category that related messages go into in Kafka.
    It is like a table in a DB or folder in a file system
    4. Partitions
    each topic is further divided into smaller partitions, which are like sub boxes inside the main topic box. Having these partitions allows different parts of the big topic to be processed in parallel by multiple brokers at the same time. Partitions also make it easy to increase processing power by simply adding more partitions as the amount of data grows.
    5. Replicas for reliability
    To ensure no data is lost if a broker fails, Kafka makes multiple copies or replicas of each partition across different brokers in the cluster. So if one broker goes down the replicas on other brokers can still serve the messages, providing reliability and preventing data loss.
    6. Offsets
    Offsets is a sequence of id's given to messages as they arrive at a partition. Once the offset is assigned it will never be changed. The first message gets offset zero. the next gets offset of one, and so on.
    7. Messages
    These messages can contain any type of data like logs, events, records or other information from the producer
    8. Producer
    Is Application that send messages only to Kafka server
    9. Consumer
    Is Application that reads messages from Kafka server
    10. Consumer Groups
    A Consumer group contains one or more consumers working together to process the messages.
    11. Fault Tolerance
    Kafka provides the fault tolerance by making the multiple copies ( replicas ) of the data. Each partitions data is copied across different brokers. If one broker fails the another broker with the replica can easily take over as the leader ensuring operations keep running and the data remains available.
    ); }; export default O1_Introduction;

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O1_IntroMicroServ = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (

üîê Microservices Security with Spring Boot

In a microservices setup, security is not just authentication & authorization, but also covers:
  • Protecting communication between services
  • Centralizing user management
  • Securing APIs exposed to clients
  • Handling tokens and sessionless authentication
    •

    üîπ Common Security Challenges in Microservices

  • Distributed authentication ‚Üí Each service can‚Äôt handle login separately.
  • Authorization ‚Üí Different services may need different permissions.
  • Token management ‚Üí Stateless auth (JWT, OAuth2 ).
  • Service-to-service trust ‚Üí Preventing unauthorized services from calling each other.
  • Data security ‚Üí Protecting sensitive info in transit (HTTPS, mTLS).

    • üîπ Security Approaches in Spring Boot Microservices

    1. API Gateway Security

  • All requests go through the API Gateway (Spring Cloud Gateway).
  • Apply authentication & authorization at the gateway level.
  • Gateway validates tokens before forwarding requests to microservices.
    •

    2. Authentication & Authorization

  • Use Spring Security with OAuth2.0 / OpenID Connect.
  • Common Identity Providers:
  • Keycloak
  • Okta
  • Auth0
  • Azure AD
    •
  • Clients (mobile/web) authenticate once, receive a JWT access token, and send it with each request.

    • 3. JWT (JSON Web Tokens)

  • Popular for microservices since they are stateless.
  • Each request carries a signed token (Authorization: Bearer {""}).
  • Services verify the token signature using a shared secret or public key.
  • Contains claims like sub, roles, exp.
    •

    4. Service-to-Service Security

  • Microservices talk securely with each other using:
  • mTLS (Mutual TLS) ‚Üí verifies both client and server.
  • OAuth2 client credentials flow ‚Üí services request tokens to call other services.
    •

    5. Centralized Config Security

  • Use Spring Cloud Config + Vault (or AWS Secrets Manager, Azure Key Vault).
  • Store secrets and credentials securely.
    •

    6. Distributed Tracing with Security

  • Use Spring Cloud Sleuth + Zipkin for request tracing.
  • Ensure tokens are propagated securely between services.
    •

    üîπ Best Practices

  • Always use HTTPS (TLS).
  • Validate JWTs (expiry, issuer, audience).
  • Use short-lived tokens + refresh tokens.
  • Principle of least privilege ‚Üí assign minimal roles/claims.
  • Externalize secrets (don‚Äôt hardcode in application.properties).
  • Consider Zero Trust: every request is authenticated, even internal.
    •

    ‚úÖ So in short:

  • Authentication & Authorization ‚Üí OAuth2 + JWT (Keycloak/Okta/Auth0).
  • Gateway Security ‚Üí Validate all tokens at entry.
  • Service Security ‚Üí Each service validates JWT + uses mTLS or client credentials for inter-service calls.
  • Secret Management ‚Üí Vault or Config Server with encryption.
    •
    ); }; export default O1_IntroMicroServ;

In Postman, a collection is a group of saved API requests that you can organize, share, and run together.
Think of it as a folder or workspace where you store related API calls (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc.) along with their parameters, headers, and body data.
  • Globals - can be use with all projects
  • Privte - Will be used only for a collection I will assign it to (can Be any project)
    • üîë Key Features of Collections:
  • Organized Requests ‚Äì Group requests by project, service, or workflow.
  • Reusable Data ‚Äì Can use collection variables or environment variables (e.g.,{" "} {"{{ baseUrl }}"} ) across requests. (see section Environment )
  • Documentation ‚Äì Add descriptions, examples, and notes for each request.
  • Collaboration ‚Äì Share collections with your team via Postman‚Äôs workspace or export as a JSON file.
  • Automation ‚Äì Run requests as collections in sequence using the Collection Runner or Postman‚Äôs newman CLI.

üîπ What are Collection Variables in Postman?

  • Collection variables are variables that belong to a specific collection in Postman.
  • They can be used across all requests inside that collection .
  • Useful for base URLs, authentication tokens, common headers, or IDs that multiple requests need.

    • üîπ Variable Scope in Postman

    ‚ö° Postman has multiple variable scopes, and collection variables sit in the middle.
    ‚ö° Priority order (lowest to highest): Global ‚Üí Collection ‚Üí Environment ‚Üí Data ‚Üí Local
  • Global ‚Üí Available everywhere.
  • Collection ‚Üí Available to all requests in a collection.
  • Environment ‚Üí Available within a chosen environment.
  • Local ‚Üí Only within the current request.
  • Data ‚Üí From external files during collection runs.
    •
    ); }; export default O3_CollectionVariables;

üß† Global Search
A global search is a pretty common developer-portal / documentation-site style feature ‚Äî but tricky to implement efficiently if not planned carefully. example:
  • Search for a text string across all ~200 pages,
  • Show matching results in a dropdown
  • On click, navigate to that page and scroll to the specific line (or component / section).
    • üß† Core Challenges
  • Searching all pages at runtime is expensive ‚Äî React apps are bundled, not file-based on the client.
  • You‚Äôll need a search index (a list of searchable content + routes).
  • You can‚Äôt literally scroll to a ‚Äúline‚Äù number (React doesn‚Äôt preserve source line info), but you can scroll to an{" "} element with an anchor ID or highlight that section.
    • ‚öôÔ∏è Recommended Architecture
    Prebuilt Search Index (best for static or large sites) , If your pages are mostly static (e.g., docs, text-heavy, not API data-driven not API data-driven):
  • Extract content at build time (using a script ).
  • Parse your /src/pages directory.
  • Read text / headings.
  • Store {"{ path, title, snippet, anchor }"} entries.
  • Build a lightweight index (e.g., JSON file)
  • If you want fuzzy search with indexing but easier TypeScript support than FlexSearch
  • Fuse.js ‚Üí very lightweight, zero build issues, TypeScript ready.
  • Lunr.js ‚Üí full-text search, small JSON index, also TS compatible.
  • FlexSearch - I did not succeed to work with it in TypeScript
  • create a Client-side search component
  • On each target page, ensure important sections have IDs so #anchor navigation works
    •
    ); }; export default O1_IntroMemorySearch;

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, JavaHighlight, SpanRed, SpanSky } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O2_InMemoryVsDB = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return ( Let's see few concepts before diving into JPA.
üîπ 1. Spring In-Memory (Java Objects)
  • This refers to the Java objects you create and manipulate in your application code.
  • These objects are not yet managed by JPA/Hibernate until you explicitly persist them.
  • A data storage approach where objects/data are kept in the system‚Äôs RAM but managed in a way that it can persist across certain operations within an application.
  • Example :
    At this point, user is just a regular Java object (POJO), not tracked by JPA.
    • In-Memory First
  • The application keeps the objects/data in memory for fast access.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    üîπ 2. Persistence Context (Managed by EntityManager)
  • This is the first-level cache managed by JPA's EntityManager. When you persist an entity, it enters the persistence context and is tracked for changes.
  • Key Characteristics:
  • Changes to entities in this context are automatically detected and synchronized with the database during a flush.
  • Entities are attached (managed).
  • Avoids unnecessary database queries by caching entities.
    •
  • Example :
    Now user is in the persistence context (saved ,but SQL NOT done yet).
    If you change user.setName("Bob"), JPA will detect this and update the DB on flush.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    {/* */} {/* */}
    Database (DB)
  • Definition
    A durable storage system, usually on disk or SSD, that stores structured data and ensures long-term persistence.
  • Characteristics
  • Durable: Data persists even if the application crashes or server restarts.
  • Supports queries: Usually comes with query languages (SQL/NoSQL APIs).
  • Concurrency & Transactions: Manages multiple users/threads with ACID guarantees (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability).
  • Slower than memory: Disk I/O is slower than RAM access, though optimizations like caching exist.
  • Examples:
  • Relational DB: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle
  • NoSQL DB: MongoDB, Cassandra
    •
    Optional Persistence
  • ‚ÄúOptional persistence‚Äù means that changes in memory don‚Äôt automatically go to the database until you explicitly request it.
  • This allows batching changes, reducing database I/O, and tracking object states.
  • You can read, modify, or delete objects directly in memory without touching the DB immediately.
    • In JPA terms
  • Objects in memory are in the persistent context (first-level cache).
  • When you call:
  • flush() ‚Üí changes in memory are pushed to the database without committing the transaction.
  • commit() ‚Üí changes are saved permanently.
    • ); }; export default O2_InMemoryVsDB; const pojo = `User user = new User("sshalem");`; const persist = `entityManager.persist(user);`;

Note: actions as SAVE, UPDATE , DELETE ,must be performed inside a a Transactional method.
  • method must be public when perfroming any of these actions (SAVE, UPDATE, DELETE)
  • must annotated method with @Transactional to keep the session open as long

  • I will show , what happens when SAVE action is perfrom. It is very important to understand since it will give a great understanding of creating these sactions.
    In addition, In the topic of Transaction Management it becomes essential
    save() , flush() , commit()
    • save()
    • Purpose: Register a new or updated entity in the persistence context (Hibernate‚Äôs first-level cache).
    • Behavior:
    • The entity becomes managed.
    • Hibernate tracks changes for dirty checking
    • No SQL is guaranteed immediately; SQL may be delayed until flush or commit.
    • Usage
    • flush()
    • Purpose : Force Hibernate to synchronize the in-memory state with the database immediately.
    • Behavior:
    • Executes INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE for all managed entities in the current persistence context.
    • Does not commit the transaction ‚Äî changes can still be rolled back.
    • Usage
    • commit()
    • Purpose : Finalize the transaction.
    • Behavior:
    • Automatically triggers a flush() if not done already.
    • Makes all changes permanent in the database.
    • After commit, changes cannot be rolled back.
    • Usage
    ); }; export default O3_SaveFlushCommit; const save_parent = `Parent p = new Parent(); p.setName("John"); parentRepository.save(p); // registered in persistence context , No SQL necessarily sent yet`; const flush_parent = `Parent p = new Parent(); p.setName("John"); parentRepository.save(p); // in-memory parentRepository.flush(); // SQL INSERT executed now`; const commit_parent = `@Transactional public void updateUser(Long id, String newName) { User user = userRepo.findById(id).orElseThrow(); user.setName(newName); // 1Ô∏è‚É£ in memory, Hibernate marks the entity as dirty (changed). userRepo.save(user); // 2Ô∏è‚É£ JPA checks if it‚Äôs new or existing. If exist ‚Üí schedule an UPDATE. // No SQL executed yet (just staged in persistence context). // Still no flush/commit. } // 3Ô∏è‚É£ Commit (end of @Transactional method) . // (commit happens here automatically) // On method exit, Spring calls commit: (Spring ends the transaction. ) // But , Before commit, // Hibernate automatically calls flush // and Executes all staged SQL. // Then commit happens: Changes are permanently stored in DB. // TX is closed`;

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, JavaHighlight, SpanTeal } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O4_HibernateSession = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
In Hibernate, a Session is the primary interface used to interact with the database.
  • Definition :
    A Session in Hibernate is a lightweight, single-threaded object that represents a connection (a unit of work) between the Java application and the database.
  • Responsibilities :
  • It acts as a bridge between the application‚Äôs objects and database tables.
  • Provides methods to create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) persistent objects.
  • Manages the first-level cache (objects stored in memory during a session).
  • Handles transactions, queries (HQL/SQL), and object state transitions (Transient ‚Üí Persistent ‚Üí Detached).
  • Lifecycle :
  • A Session is created by a SessionFactory.
  • Typically opened when you start a unit of work and closed once the work is finished.
  • It should not be kept open for too long because it holds resources.
    • {/* */} {/* */} {/* */}
    {/* */} {/* */}
    JPA Repository with Hibernate
    ‚úÖ In short:

    With Spring Boot JPA repositories, you don‚Äôt deal with Session directly ‚Äî but every call goes through one, managed by Spring and Hibernate.

    1. Spring Data JPA and EntityManager
  • In JPA (the standard), the main interface to interact with the database is EntityManager.
  • When you use JpaRepository, Spring injects an EntityManager for you.
  • Underneath, Hibernate implements JPA, so Spring actually provides a Hibernate-backed EntityManager.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    2. EntityManager and Hibernate Session
  • Hibernate‚Äôs Session is its native API.
  • The JPA EntityManager is essentially a wrapper around the Hibernate Session.
  • entityManager.unwrap(Session.class) gives you the Hibernate Session.
  • So when you call userRepository.save(user), Spring ‚Üí JPA ‚Üí Hibernate ‚Üí Session ‚Üí JDBC ‚Üí SQL.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    3. Transaction Boundaries
  • In Spring Boot, transactions are usually managed with @Transactional.
  • Within a transaction:
  • Spring opens a Hibernate Session and binds it to the current thread.
  • All repository methods inside that transaction share the same Session.
  • This enables features like:
  • First-level cache (entities are fetched once and reused in the session).
  • Dirty checking (Hibernate tracks entity changes and flushes SQL automatically before commit).
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    4. Example
    {/* */} {/* */}
    5. Key Flow
  • Repository ‚Üí EntityManager ‚Üí Hibernate Session ‚Üí JDBC ‚Üí Database.
  • So when you call userRepository.save(user), Spring JPA ‚Üí Hibernate Session ‚Üí JDBC ‚Üí SQL.
  • The Session is usually invisible to us because Spring manages it.
  • But if needed, you can access it by define the EntityManager and annotate it with @PersistenceContext
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    ); }; export default O4_HibernateSession; const transaction_example = `@Service public class UserService { @Autowired private UserRepository userRepository; @Transactional public void updateUserEmail(Long id, String newEmail) { // Behind the scenes: a Hibernate Session is opened & bound User user = userRepository.findById(id).orElseThrow(); // Modify entity user.setEmail(newEmail); // Since we are inside a @TRansactionl method , // No explicit save needed! Hibernate Session will detect change (Dirty Checking) // and flush UPDATE SQL before transaction commits. } }`; const entitymanager = `@PersistenceContext private EntityManager em; public void doSomething() { Session session = em.unwrap(Session.class); // Now you can use Hibernate-specific APIs }`;

import { Anchor, Li, MainChildArea, ULdisc } from "../../../../../components"; import { SpanGrey } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; const O5_TransactionMngmnt = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
Spring Boot Transaction management is a mechanism that ensures data consistency and integrity when performing multiple database operations.
It allows a group of operations to execute as a single unit of work ‚Äî either all succeed or all fail (rolled back).

üîë Isolation : Data anomalies

There three classic data anomalies that can occur in DB transactions under different isolation levels.
These are fundamental concepts in transaction management and concurrency control ‚Äî especially important when tuning Spring Boot applications for data consistency and performance. See more data in section{" "}
  • üëâ Dirty Reads
  • üëâ Non-Repeatable Reads
  • üëâ Phantom Reads
    •
    ); }; export default O5_TransactionMngmnt;

import { Li, MainChildArea, ULdisc } from "../../../../../components"; import { SpanGreen, SpanGrey } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; const O6_WhatIsTransaction = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (

üîë What Is a Transaction

  • A logical unit of work that can include one or more database operations (queries, inserts, updates, deletes).
  • Guarantees ACID properties , and A transaction must follow the ACID properties:
  • Atomicity : A transaction should be treated as a single unit of operation, which means either the entire sequence of operations is successful or unsuccessful
  • Consistency : The DB remains in a consistent state before and after the transaction.
  • Isolation : Transactions do not affect each other‚Äôs intermediate states. There may be many transaction processing with the same data set at the same time. Each transaction should be isolated from others to prevent data corruption.
  • Durability : Once committed, the changes are permanent.
    • {/* */} {/* */}

    üîë Spring‚Äôs Role

  • Spring provides a declarative way (with @Transactional) to define where transactions start and end.
  • Spring automatically:
  • Begins a transaction before your method runs.
  • Commits the transaction if the method finishes normally.
  • Rolls back the transaction if an exception occurs.
    •
    {/* */} {/* */}

    üîë How It Works

  • You annotate your service-layer methods with @Transactional.
  • Under the hood:
  • Spring creates a proxy around your class.
  • The proxy starts/commits/rolls back a transaction around your method execution.
  • The actual DB work is done by Hibernate (or JPA) within that transaction.
    •
    ); }; export default O6_WhatIsTransaction;

Transaction management in Spring is the mechanism by which Spring ensures that a group of database operations are executed as a single unit of work ‚Äî meaning all succeed or all fail.

üîë Key Concepts

{/* */} {/* */} {/* */}
{/* */} {/* */}
1. Transaction
  • A logical unit of work that can include one or more database operations (queries, inserts, updates, deletes).
  • Guarantees ACID properties:
  • Atomicity: All or nothing.
  • Consistency: Keeps DB valid.
  • Isolation: Transactions don‚Äôt interfere incorrectly.
  • Durability: Once committed, data is saved.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    2. Spring‚Äôs Role
  • Spring provides a declarative way (with @Transactional) to define where transactions start and end.
  • Spring automatically:
  • Begins a transaction before your method runs.
  • Commits the transaction if the method finishes normally.
  • Rolls back the transaction if an exception occurs.
    •
    {/* */} {/* */}
    3. How It Works
  • You annotate your service-layer methods with @Transactional.
  • Under the hood:
  • Spring creates a proxy around your class.
  • The proxy starts/commits/rolls back a transaction around your method execution.
  • The actual DB work is done by Hibernate (or JPA) within that transaction.
    •
    {/* */} {/* */}
    ); }; export default O5_SpringTxMngmnt;

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, JavaHighlight, SpanRed, SpanSky } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O2_InMemoryVsDB = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return ( Let's see few concepts before diving into JPA.
üîπ 1. Spring In-Memory (Java Objects)
  • This refers to the Java objects you create and manipulate in your application code.
  • These objects are not yet managed by JPA/Hibernate until you explicitly persist them.
  • A data storage approach where objects/data are kept in the system‚Äôs RAM but managed in a way that it can persist across certain operations within an application.
  • Example :
    At this point, user is just a regular Java object (POJO), not tracked by JPA.
    • In-Memory First
  • The application keeps the objects/data in memory for fast access.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    üîπ 2. Persistence Context (Managed by EntityManager)
  • This is the first-level cache managed by JPA's EntityManager. When you persist an entity, it enters the persistence context and is tracked for changes.
  • Key Characteristics:
  • Changes to entities in this context are automatically detected and synchronized with the database during a flush.
  • Entities are attached (managed).
  • Avoids unnecessary database queries by caching entities.
    •
  • Example :
    Now user is in the persistence context (saved ,but SQL NOT done yet).
    If you change user.setName("Bob"), JPA will detect this and update the DB on flush.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    {/* */} {/* */}
    Database (DB)
  • Definition
    A durable storage system, usually on disk or SSD, that stores structured data and ensures long-term persistence.
  • Characteristics
  • Durable: Data persists even if the application crashes or server restarts.
  • Supports queries: Usually comes with query languages (SQL/NoSQL APIs).
  • Concurrency & Transactions: Manages multiple users/threads with ACID guarantees (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability).
  • Slower than memory: Disk I/O is slower than RAM access, though optimizations like caching exist.
  • Examples:
  • Relational DB: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle
  • NoSQL DB: MongoDB, Cassandra
    •
    Optional Persistence
  • ‚ÄúOptional persistence‚Äù means that changes in memory don‚Äôt automatically go to the database until you explicitly request it.
  • This allows batching changes, reducing database I/O, and tracking object states.
  • You can read, modify, or delete objects directly in memory without touching the DB immediately.
    • In JPA terms
  • Objects in memory are in the persistent context (first-level cache).
  • When you call:
  • flush() ‚Üí changes in memory are pushed to the database without committing the transaction.
  • commit() ‚Üí changes are saved permanently.

In Hibernate, a Session is the primary interface used to interact with the database.

  • Responsibilities :

  • Manages the first-level cache (objects stored in memory during a session).
  • Handles transactions, queries (HQL/SQL), and object state transitions (Transient ‚Üí Persistent ‚Üí Detached).
  • Lifecycle :
  • A Session is created by a SessionFactory.
  • Typically opened when you start a unit of work and closed once the work is finished.
  • It should not be kept open for too long because it holds resources.

  • Within a transaction:
  • Spring opens a Hibernate Session and binds it to the current thread.
  • All repository methods inside that transaction share the same Session.
  • This enables features like:
  • First-level cache (entities are fetched once and reused in the session).
  • Dirty checking (Hibernate tracks entity changes and flushes SQL automatically before commit).
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    4. Example
    {/* */} {/* */}
    5. Key Flow
  • Repository ‚Üí EntityManager ‚Üí Hibernate Session ‚Üí JDBC ‚Üí Database.
  • So when you call userRepository.save(user), Spring JPA ‚Üí Hibernate Session ‚Üí JDBC ‚Üí SQL.
  • The Session is usually invisible to us because Spring manages it.
  • But if needed, you can access it by define the EntityManager and annotate it with @PersistenceContext
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    ); }; export default O4_HibernateSession; const transaction_example = `@Service public class UserService { @Autowired private UserRepository userRepository; @Transactional public void updateUserEmail(Long id, String newEmail) { // Behind the scenes: a Hibernate Session is opened & bound User user = userRepository.findById(id).orElseThrow(); // Modify entity user.setEmail(newEmail); // Since we are inside a @TRansactionl method , // No explicit save needed! Hibernate Session will detect change (Dirty Checking) // and flush UPDATE SQL before transaction commits. } }`; const entitymanager = `@PersistenceContext private EntityManager em; public void doSomething() { Session session = em.unwrap(Session.class); // Now you can use Hibernate-specific APIs }`;

what is the difference between CommandLineRunner to @PostConstruct and{" "} data.sql ?

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

CommandLineRunner , @PostConstruct, and data.sql are three different mechanisms in Spring Boot used for
initializing data or running logic at application startup,
but they serve different purposes, have different scopes, and are executed at different phases of the app lifecycle.

‚è±Ô∏è Order of Execution

If you use all three, this is roughly the order:

  • schema.sql (if present)
  • data.sql
  • Beans initialized ‚Üí @PostConstruct methods run
  • Spring context ready ‚Üí CommandLineRunner.run() executed

/* /spring/application-properties/db-initialization#2.Schemasql Schema sql --> (SPRING)(ApplicationProperties)(Schema sql) */ import { IMG, MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { ApplicationPropertiesHighlight, DivDoubleBorder, SpanBlue } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import db_init_1 from "../../../../../assets/db_init_1.jpg"; import db_init_2 from "../../../../../assets/db_init_2.jpg"; const O2_DBInitSchemaSql = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return ( In Spring Boot, schema.sql is a SQL script file used to define and initialize the database schema (i.e., tables, constraints, indexes) when the application starts. schema.sql contains raw SQL statements (like CREATE TABLE, ALTER, etc.) that Spring Boot runs at startup to set up the database structure before inserting any data (via data.sql).
If there's{" "} NO {" "} data.sql, no initial data will be inserted.
Default behavior, Spring Boot looks for:
  • schema.sql ‚Üí for schema creation
  • data.sql ‚Üí for initial data. If there's no data.sql, no initial data will be inserted.
  • They are executed in order: first schema.sql, then data.sql.
schema.sql located in   src/main/resources
When you place schema.sql in src/main/resources, Spring Boot automatically detects it. (if database initialization spring.sql.init.mode=always is enabled)
When using schema.sql configure your application.properties like this :
  • spring.sql.init.mode=always - Enable execution of schema.sql and{" "} data.sql
  • spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=none - when using schema.sql , Don't let Hibernate auto-create the schema
  • spring.jpa.defer-datasource-initialization=true - Makes Spring Boot run SQL scripts before Hibernate initializes (important!). Ensure schema.sql runs BEFORE JPA starts (important!)
{/* */} {/* */}
schema.sql located in{" "} src/main/resources/sqlSchemas/schema.sql
Let's say I want to put schema.sql{" "} in different folder {" "} src/main/resources/sqlSchemas/schema.sql, we need to tell spring boot about this new path , in order for spring to detect it.
Then, configure your application.properties like this.
This tells Spring Boot to load{" "} schema.sql from /sqlSchemas/ instead of the default root of resources.
Note :
Most of the time, I don't use schema.sql (I use data.sql) , I prefer   automatic schema generation.
Spring Boot can create tables from your JPA @Entity classes using:

/* /spring/application-properties/db-initialization#3.Datasql Data sql --> (SPRING)(ApplicationProperties)(Data sql) */ import { IMG, MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { ApplicationPropertiesHighlight, DivDoubleBorder, SpanBlue } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import db_init_3 from "../../../../../assets/db_init_3.jpg"; import db_init_4 from "../../../../../assets/db_init_4.jpg"; const O3_DBInitDataSql = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return ( data.sql is an SQL file commonly used in Spring Boot ,that contains SQL statements to{" "} initialize or populate {" "} a relational database when the application starts. It usually includes:
  • INSERT statements to prepopulate tables with data.
  • Occasionally DELETE, UPDATE, or even SELECT statements (though this is rare).
  • It's purely optional‚Äîmeant for seeding the database with initial data, often for development or testing purposes.
Spring Boot :
  • automatically loads data.sql (along with schema.sql if present) from the{" "} classpath when the application starts.
  • It runs after the schema is created
data.sql located in{" "} src/main/resources
When you place data.sql in src/main/resources, Spring Boot automatically detects it. (if database initialization spring.sql.init.mode=always is enabled)
When using data.sql configure your application.properties like this :
  • spring.sql.init.mode=always - Enable execution of schema.sql and{" "} data.sql
  • spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=create - tell Hibernate (the JPA provider) to automatically generate the database schema at runtime by creating tables based on your JPA entity classes.
  • spring.jpa.generate-ddl=true - When set to true, Spring will ask the JPA provider (usually Hibernate) to automatically create or update the database schema based on your entity definitions (@Entity, @Column, etc.).
  • spring.jpa.defer-datasource-initialization=true - Makes Spring Boot run SQL scripts before Hibernate initializes (important!). Ensure schema.sql runs BEFORE JPA starts (important!)
Default behavior, Spring Boot looks for:
  • schema.sql ‚Üí for schema creation
  • data.sql ‚Üí for initial data. If there's no data.sql, no initial data will be inserted.
  • They are executed in order: first schema.sql, then data.sql.
{/* */} {/* */}
data.sql located in{" "} src/main/resources/sqlData/data.sql
Let's say I want to put data.sql{" "} in different folder {" "} src/main/resources/sqlData/data.sql, we need to tell spring boot about this new path , in order for spring to detect it.
Then, configure your application.properties like this.
This tells Spring Boot to load{" "} data.sql from /sqlData/ instead of the default root of resources.
); }; export default O3_DBInitDataSql; const dataSqlCode = `spring.sql.init.mode=always spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=create spring.jpa.generate-ddl=true spring.jpa.defer-datasource-initialization=true `; const dataSqlDifferentPathCode = `spring.sql.init.mode=always spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto=create spring.jpa.generate-ddl=true spring.sql.init.schema-locations=classpath:sqlData/data.sql spring.jpa.defer-datasource-initialization=true `;

refernce link
https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/reference/features/logging.html
By default, Spring Boot logs only to the console and does not write log files.
If you want to write log files in addition to the console output, you need to set a :
  • logging.file.name
  • or logging.file.path property (for example, in your application.properties).
If both properties are set   logging.file.path   is ignored, and only   logging.file.name   is used.
Important note
  • System.out.println() writes only (directly) to the console (not to file), and bypasses the logging framework entirely.
  • Spring Boot‚Äôs logging() (e.g., via SLF4J, Logback, or Log4j2) is configured to write logs to both the console and optionally a file.
{/* */}
There are 4 possible options to configure Spring Boot Logging with logging file on production server (see Spring docs )

SLF4J - Simple{" "} L ogging Facade   for Java.
It‚Äôs not a logging implementation by itself, but rather a facade or abstraction for various logging frameworks (e.g., Logback, Log4j, java.util.logging). It allows your application code to remain independent of the underlying logging framework.
Links with examples of how to config:
  • DZone
  • Baeldung
  • MyKong
  • Configuring Logback with Spring Boot
  • Logback   and   logback manual
  • Spring Doc 2.7.6 - Logging
  • Logback HTML layout
  • Logback Video
{/* */} {/* */}
Why Logback
  • Logback is a successor to log4j
  • Great improvement over log4j
  • Faster & smaller memory footprint thatn log4j
  • Implements SLF4J natively
  • Automatic reloading of configuration files
  • Automatic removal of old log archives
  • Automatic compression of archived log files
  • Filters : used-based logging, thread-based logging
{/* */} {/* */}
Rolling file setup in application.properties
  • logging.file.path
  • logging.file.name
  • logging.pattern.file
  • logging.pattern.rolling-file-name
  • logging.file.max.size (default: 10MB)
  • logging.file.max.history (default: 7 days)
  • logging.file.total-size-cap
  • logging.file.clean-history-on-start
{/* */} {/* */} ); }; export default Slf4jLinks;

import { Link } from "react-router-dom"; import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, JavaHighlight, SpanRed, SpanSky, SpanTeal } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import TableCompareOrphanVsCascadeRemove from "../../../../../components/Tables/TableCompareOrphanVsCascadeRemove"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULDecimal from "../../../../../components/ui/ULDecimal"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O1_IntroO2M = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (

Let's see few concepts before diving into @OneToMany

for more comprehansive see{" "} Tansaction Management setions 1-5

üîπ 1. Spring In-Memory (Java Objects)
  • This refers to the Java objects you create and manipulate in your application code.
  • These objects are not yet managed by JPA/Hibernate until you explicitly persist them.
  • A data storage approach where objects/data are kept in the system‚Äôs RAM but managed in a way that it can persist across certain operations within an application.
  • Example :
    At this point, user is just a regular Java object (POJO), not tracked by JPA.
    • In-Memory First
  • The application keeps the objects/data in memory for fast access.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    üîπ 2. Persistence Context (Managed by EntityManager)
  • This is the first-level cache managed by JPA's EntityManager. When you persist an entity, it enters the persistence context and is tracked for changes.
  • Key Characteristics:
  • Changes to entities in this context are automatically detected and synchronized with the database during a flush.
  • Entities are attached (managed).
  • Avoids unnecessary database queries by caching entities.
    •
  • Example :
    Now user is in the persistence context (saved ,but SQL NOT done yet).
    If you change user.setName("Bob"), JPA will detect this and update the DB on flush.
    • {/* */} {/* */}
    {/* */} {/* */}
    Database (DB)
  • Definition
    A durable storage system, usually on disk or SSD, that stores structured data and ensures long-term persistence.
  • Characteristics
  • Durable: Data persists even if the application crashes or server restarts.
  • Supports queries: Usually comes with query languages (SQL/NoSQL APIs).
  • Concurrency & Transactions: Manages multiple users/threads with ACID guarantees (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability).
  • Slower than memory: Disk I/O is slower than RAM access, though optimizations like caching exist.
  • Examples:
  • Relational DB: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle
  • NoSQL DB: MongoDB, Cassandra
    •
    {/* */} {/* */} {/* */}
    Cascade Types
    In JPA/Hibernate, when you use a @OneToMany relationship, the cascade attribute defines which operations performed on the parent entity should be automatically propagated to its child entities.
  • CascadeType.PERSIST - When saving the parent, the children will also be saved automatically.
  • CascadeType.MERGE - When updating the parent, changes to children will also be merged
  • CascadeType.REMOVE - When deleting the parent, the children will also be deleted.
  • CascadeType.REFRESH - Refreshing the parent also refreshes children from the database.
  • CascadeType.DETACH - Detaching the parent will also detach children from the persistence context.
  • CascadeType.ALL Applies all of the above cascade operations.
    •
    {/* */} {/* */} {/* */} {/* */}
    orphanRemoval orphanRemoval = true tells Hibernate:
    ‚ÄúIf a child entity is no longer referenced by its parent collection or field, treat it as an orphan and delete it from the database.‚Äù
    Meaning,
    if I remove an entity from the parent‚Äôs relationship in memory, Hibernate will automatically issue a DELETE for that entity when I flush/commit.
    ‚ö° Difference from cascade = CascadeType.REMOVE
  • cascade = REMOVE only propagates when the parent entity itself is removed.
  • orphanRemoval = true works even when the parent stays alive but you just drop a child from its collection.

    • üëâ In short:

  • Use orphanRemoval = true when the child cannot exist without the parent (e.g., Order ‚Üí OrderLine).
  • Don‚Äôt use it if the child may live independently or move to another parent (e.g., Department ‚Üí Student if students can transfer).
    •
    Important Note

    for the behaviors in that table to actually take effect, you need to make sure that your operations run inside a transaction. Here‚Äôs why...

    Why @Transactional is needed

  • JPA/Hibernate doesn‚Äôt execute SQL immediately.
  • Changes you make (remove(), parent.getChildren().remove(child), etc.) are tracked in the persistence context first.
  • The actual DELETE / UPDATE SQL statements are flushed to the database only when:
  • The transaction is committed, or
  • You explicitly call entityManager.flush().
    •
    ); }; export default O1_IntroO2M; const pojo = `User user = new User("sshalem");`; const persist = `entityManager.persist(user);`;

CascadeType.PERSIST - means save. When saving the parent, the children will also be saved automatically.
it only propagates when SQL insert queries are executed (Not UPDATE etc...)
In the following sections , I will add each cascade type at a time.
I will examine the Persistent Context and{" "} DataBase with and w/o the cascade type.
  • NO cascade
  • {"cascade = {CascadeType.PERSIST}"}
    • UserEntity w/o CascadeType.PERSIST
  • Setup UserEntity w/o Cascade
    • {" "}
  • Open Postman
  • Select 02-Spring-JPA ‚Üí oneToMany ‚Üí Users API
  • send a POST request of createUserWithRoles
  • The Request I sent , Includes new User with 2 Roles.
    Note - I return ENTITY NOT DTO ,let's see what happens. controller code
  • Lets examine Hibernate SQL query and DataBase
    •
    let's examine the behabior
  • Hibernate SQL - as Expected , only insert to user executed, there is no insert{" "} to role_tb, .
    Since there is no CASCADE PERSIST

import { Li, MainChildArea, ULdisc } from "../../../../../components"; import { SpanGreen, SpanRed, SpanSky } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import TableCompareMerge from "../../../../../components/Tables/TableCompareMerge"; const O4_LazyCascadeMerge = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
CascadeType.MERGE - means update. When updating the parent, the children will also be updated automatically.
it only propagates when SQL update queries are executed (Not INSERT etc...)
In the following sections , I will add each cascade type at a time.
I will examine the Persistent Context and{" "} DataBase with and w/o the cascade type.
üîç Scenario Recap
  • I have a Parent entity with a {"List"}.
  • The relationship is bidirectional:
  • Parent has @OneToMany(mappedBy = "parent")
  • Child has @ManyToOne
    •
  • I do not use CascadeType.MERGE.
  • I update the parent and add or modify children.
    • ‚ùå What You Won‚Äôt See in the Database Automatically
  • Changes to child entities will NOT be persisted or merged unless you explicitly call{" "} entityManager.merge(child) or entityManager.persist(child) yourself (This is why we add CASCADE MERGE ).
  • The parent update will be saved, but the child changes will be ignored unless manually handled.
    • ‚úÖ What You Will See
  • The parent entity‚Äôs changes (e.g., name, status) will be reflected in the DB.
  • The child list may appear unchanged in the DB unless you:
  • Explicitly persist/merge the child.
  • Use cascading (CascadeType.MERGE or ALL).
    •
    üîÑ Summary
    ); }; export default O4_LazyCascadeMerge;

import { Li, MainChildArea, ULdisc } from "../../../../../components"; import { JavaHighlight, SpanRed } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; const O6_LazyCascadeDetach = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
What CascadeType.DETACH means?
  • "Detach" means the entity is removed from the persistence context (the first-level cache).
  • When you call entityManager.detach(parent) on a parent, JPA will also detach all its children{" "} if the relationship has cascade = CascadeType.DETACH.
  • After detaching:
  • Changes you make won‚Äôt be automatically synchronized to the database.
  • You‚Äôd need to call merge() or save again for updates.
    • With JpaRepository
    Spring Data JPA repositories internally use the EntityManager.
  • If you call repository.save(parent), it eventually does persist or merge ‚Üí{" "} not detach.
  • Repositories do not expose a detach() method.
  • That means CascadeType.DETACH will not be triggered automatically when using repositories, because{" "} repository methods don‚Äôt call detach.
    • 1. Managed entity (attached)
    When an entity is inside the persistence context (attached/managed):
  • Any change you make to it is tracked by Hibernate (dirty checking).
  • At flush/commit, Hibernate automatically generates the SQL to update the DB.
    •
    2. Detached entity
    When you call em.detach(entity) or the persistence context is closed:{" "}
  • The entity is no longer tracked.
  • Changes you make are not recorded.
  • At commit, Hibernate won‚Äôt generate any SQL for it.
    •
    3. Re-attaching (merge)
    If you want the DB to be updated, you must reattach it with merge():
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Note: merge() returns a new managed instance. The passed object (parent) stays detached.
    •
    ‚úÖ Summary
  • CascadeType.DETACH is supported in JPA.
  • But JpaRepository itself never calls detach().
  • To make use of it, you must explicitly call entityManager.detach(entity).
    •
    ‚úÖ So the rule is
  • Detached entity = just a plain Java object (POJO).
  • No matter what you do to it, nothing will be flushed to the DB unless you call merge().
    •
    ); }; export default O6_LazyCascadeDetach; const attached_entity = `Parent parent = em.find(Parent.class, 1L); parent.setName("new name"); // No explicit save needed ‚Äî will update DB on commit `; const de_attached_entity = `Parent parent = em.find(Parent.class, 1L); em.detach(parent); parent.setName("changed name"); // No effect in DB ‚Äî Hibernate ignores it `; const re_attach = `Parent parent = em.find(Parent.class, 1L); em.detach(parent); parent.setName("changed name"); em.merge(parent); // now changes will be applied at commit `;

import { Answer, Li, MainChildArea, Question, ULdisc } from "../../../../../components"; import { SpanBlue, SpanGreen, SpanGrey, SpanRed } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; const OO_DtoVsEntity = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
Why with Fetch Lazy, when I return Parent Entity (Not DTO) from Controller, it also retruns it's children ?
  • The problem is that serialization accesses the lazy collection (calls the getter methods of{" "} getRoles() ) , which triggers DB fetch.
  • The best practice is use DTOs. Don't return entities directly in REST APIs.
  • Lazy loading in JPA/Hibernate means:
  • The collection (roles) is a proxy.
  • It will not be loaded from the DB until you access it.
    •
  • When Spring Boot sends a UserEntity as a REST response, Jackson calls the{" "} getter methods (getRoles()), (even if LAZY) which triggers Hibernate to fetch the collection, because Jackson wants to{" "} serialize it into JSON.
  • So even though the mapping is lazy, serialization forces initialization.
  • ‚úÖ to conclude,
  • Return DTOs . And best practice , retrun from the controller not from{" "} service layer.
  • If you return Entities from the controller, the children will be serialized by Jackson, unless you suppress them{" "} (@JsonIgnore / @JsonView).{" "}
    • With Fetch Lazy , we Add annotations of @JsonManagedReference / @JsonBackReference ? What they do?
    These annotations tell Jackson:
  • Serialize this relationship, but prevent infinite recursion in bidirectional associations.
  • When Jackson serializes UserEntity, it sees roles and says: ‚û°Ô∏è "I need to serialize this collection too."
  • But since roles is LAZY and the Hibernate session is already closed (transaction ended before serialization), it tries to initialize the proxy ‚Üí üí• LazyInitializationException .
    • üîπ Why @JsonIgnore solved it
    Jackson simply skips the roles field during serialization.
  • ‚û°Ô∏è That means it never tries to touch the lazy proxy.
  • ‚û°Ô∏è No lazy load attempt ‚Üí no error.
    •      So, the difference is:
  • @JsonManagedReference / @JsonBackReference ‚Üí Jackson does serialize the relationship ‚Üí triggers lazy loading, to prevent this, we retrun DTO in contrller layer
  • @JsonIgnore ‚Üí Jackson skips the relationship ‚Üí No Serialization ‚Üí no lazy loading, no error.
    • ); }; export default OO_DtoVsEntity;

üß© What Is countQuery?

When you use pagination (Pageable) with Spring Data JPA, Spring actually runs two SQL queries behind the scenes:
  • Main query ‚Üí fetches the actual page of data (with LIMIT and OFFSET )
  • Count query ‚Üí calculates the total number of records matching your query (used for totalElements and totalPages in{" "} {"Page"} )
    • {/* */} {/* */} {/* */}

    üß† Normally ‚Äî No Need to Define It

    If you use derived queries (like findByStatus(...)) or findAll(Pageable pageable), Spring automatically generates both the main query and the count query.
    ‚úÖ Example: Spring auto-generates:
    {/* */} {/* */} {/* */}

    ‚öôÔ∏è When You Need countQuery

    When you use a custom JPQL or native query with @Query, Spring cannot always automatically figure out how to count the total records correctly.
    That‚Äôs where you manually define a countQuery.
  • value query runs with LIMIT and OFFSET
  • countQuery runs without pagination ‚Äî just to count total matching rows.

    • üß± Example with Native Query

    I used the countQuery a lot in the project of{" "}

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { DivDoubleBorder, SpanGreen, SpanRed, SpanSky } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import SpanGrey from "../../../../../components/Highlight/SpanGrey"; import TableCompareJPQL from "../../../../../components/Tables/TableCompareJPQL"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O1_IntroJpql = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (
JPQL (Java Persistence Query Language) is a powerful query language used in Java applications that interact with databases via JPA (Java Persistence API).
It‚Äôs similar to SQL but operates on Java objects (entities) rather than directly on database tables.
Key Features of JPQL
  • Object-oriented: Queries are written using entity class names and field names, not table or column names.
  • Supports joins, subqueries, aggregation, and more.
    •  JPQL vs Native SQL Query
    While JPQL is powerful and covers most use cases, there are situations where using a{" "} native SQL query becomes necessary or more practical.
    ‚úÖ When JPQL Is Enough , works well for:
  • Standard CRUD operations
  • Filtering, sorting, and joining entities
  • Aggregations (COUNT, SUM, AVG, etc.)
  • Subqueries and expressions
  • Working with mapped relationships (e.g., @OneToMany, @ManyToOne)
    •
    ‚ö†Ô∏è When Native Queries Are Necessary
  • Complex SQL Features Not Supported by JPQL
  • Querying Unmapped Tables or Views (If you're accessing a table not mapped to an entity, JPQL won't work.)
  • Performance Optimization , Sometimes native queries are faster or allow better indexing/hints.
  • JPQL supports bulk updates/deletes, but native queries can be more flexible.
  • You need native SQL to call stored procedures or database functions.
    • ); }; export default O1_IntroJpql;

    • üß© What is FilterChainProxy?

  • Spring Security‚Äôs Servlet support is contained within FilterChainProxy.
  • FilterChainProxy is a special Filter provided by Spring Security that allows delegating to many Filter instances through SecurityFilterChain.
  • Since FilterChainProxy is a Bean, it is typically wrapped in a{" "} DelegatingFilterProxy.
  • It is a Servlet Filter implementation provided by Spring Security.
  • It acts as a dispatcher: instead of handling security logic itself, it delegates requests to one of multiple{" "} SecurityFilterChains.
  • Each SecurityFilterChain is essentially a list of security filters (e.g., UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter, BasicAuthenticationFilter, ExceptionTranslationFilter, etc.).
  • This delegation allows different endpoints to have different security configurations.

SecurityFilterChain is used by FilterChainProxy to determine which Spring Security Filter instances should be invoked for the current request. The following image shows the role of SecurityFilterChain.

    • üèóÔ∏è Structure

  • FilterChainProxy holds a list of SecurityFilterChains.
  • Each SecurityFilterChain:
  • Has a RequestMatcher (to decide which requests it applies to).
  • Has a list of filters (like authentication, authorization, CSRF, etc.).
    •

    ‚öôÔ∏è How it Works (Flow)

  • Your application is a Servlet app ‚Üí requests go through the standard Servlet filter chain.
  • Spring Boot auto-registers FilterChainProxy as a bean , through DelegatingFilterProxy .
  • When a request comes in:
  • FilterChainProxy looks at the request URL.
  • It finds a matching SecurityFilterChain.
  • It runs that chain‚Äôs filters in order.
    •
  • If no chain matches, the request just continues to the app with no Spring Security applied.

    • üîç Example (conceptual) , here what happens in the code

  • /api/** ‚Üí handled by the first SecurityFilterChain (requires authentication, HTTP Basic).
  • Everything else (/**) ‚Üí handled by the second chain (permit all, with form login).
  • FilterChainProxy decides which chain to use for each request.

    • üåê Request Flow

    üëç here‚Äôs a clear diagram of the request flow with FilterChainProxy in Spring Security:

  • DelegatingFilterProxy is just a bridge between Servlet container filters and Spring-managed beans.
  • FilterChainProxy is where Spring Security kicks in.
  • It decides which SecurityFilterChain applies, based on the request path (/api/** , /admin/** , etc.).
  • The chosen chain runs its filters in strict order.
  • Finally, the request continues to the DispatcherServlet, and your controller executes.

in this section I will show the difference between 2 approaches:
  • Session-based Authentication.
  • JWT-based Authentication.
    •
    ‚úÖ Rule of Thumb:
  • Use Session-based auth for traditional, server-rendered web apps where scalability isn‚Äôt a huge issue.
  • Use JWT auth for APIs, SPAs (React, Vue, Angular), mobile apps, and microservices.
    •

    üß© Session Based Authentication

    In the image below, when a user logs into a website :
    How it works:
  • User logs in ‚Üí server validates credentials.
  • Server creates a session (stored in memory, Redis, or DB).
  • A session ID is sent to the client in a cookie.
  • On each request, the client sends the cookie ‚Üí server looks up the session ‚Üí authenticates the user.
    •

    üß© JWT Based Authentication

    JWT - Json Web Token

    one of the best ways to secure ways to communicate between Client and Server.
    The Advantage of Using JWT , because it completely follows stateless authentication mechanism.

    üß© What Stateless Authentication Mechanism means?

    Stateless Authentication Mechanism means , all the users input or user state, are{" "} never saved in server memory or cookies.

    üîë How JWT works:

  • User logs in ‚Üí server validates credentials.
  • Server generates a JWT (signed token with user info/claims).
  • Token is sent to the client (usually stored in localStorage or as a cookie).
  • On each request, the client sends the token in the Authorization header (e.g., Bearer token).
  • Server verifies the signature ‚Äî no need to look up session in storage.
    •
    üîë Why JWT is considered stateless?
  • The core idea of JWT is that all the info needed to authenticate a user is inside the token itself (claims + signature).
  • When a request comes in, the server just:
  • Verifies the JWT signature (with a secret or public key).
  • Reads the claims (user ID, roles, expiry, etc.).
  • No DB lookup is required. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs called stateless authentication.
    •
    üõë But what if we store JWTs in a DB?

    Some implementations choose to store JWTs in a DB or cache (Redis) for extra features:

  • Revocation ‚Üí You want to invalidate a token before its expiry (e.g., user logs out, account compromised).
  • Tracking ‚Üí Track active tokens and block stolen ones.
  • Auditing ‚Üí Keep a record of issued tokens (login history, IP, device)
  • Refresh tokens ‚Üí often stored in DB for rotation & blacklisting.
    •

    In this case:

  • revocation logic becomes stateful ‚Äî because you‚Äôre checking the DB to see if a token is valid.
  • JWT verification is still stateless (signature + claims are self-contained).
    •
    ‚úÖ So the difference is:
  • Pure JWT auth (stateless) ‚Üí No DB lookup, token is valid until it expires.
  • JWT + DB check (stateful hybrid) ‚Üí You get revocation power, but you lose some of the stateless scalability advantage.
    • üîÑ In practice:
  • Many systems issue short-lived JWT access tokens (stateless) + longer-lived refresh tokens (stored in DB for revocation).
  • This balances performance (stateless access) and security (stateful refresh).
    •
    {/*
  • */}
    ); }; export default O6_AuthenticationApproach;

Hashing, encoding, and encrypting are all techniques used in computing and data security, but they serve different purposes.
They all are used to change the format of the data or data transformation for different purposes.

Note JWT (JSON Web Token) does not use encryption by default, especially in typical Spring Boot implementations.
{" "} Instead, it uses signing to ensure the integrity and authenticity of the token.

üîç Here's how JWT works in Spring Boot

1. Signing (Not Encryption)

  • JWTs are usually signed using algorithms like HMAC SHA-256 or RSA.
  • This signature ensures that the token has not been tampered with.
  • The payload (user data) is visible and not encrypted, but it's protected by the signature.
    •

    2. Encryption (Optional)

  • If you want to hide the contents of the JWT (not just verify integrity), you need to use JWE (JSON Web Encryption).
  • Spring Boot does not use JWE by default ‚Äî you would need to implement it manually or use a library that supports it.
    • {/* */}
    {/* */}

    üîê 1. Encryption

    Encryption is an encoding technique in which a message is encoded by using an{" "} encryption algorithm in such a way that ,
    only authorized personnel can access the message or information.
    It is a special type of encoding that is used for transferring private data, for example :
  • sending a combination of username and password over the internet for email login.
    •  In encryption, data to be encrypted(called plain text) :
  • is transformed using an encryption algorithm like AES or RSA Encryption Algorithm
  • using a secret key called a cipher (The encrypted data is called ciphertext)
  • and finally, the secret key can be used by the intended recipient to convert it back to plain text.
    •

    üîÅ Encryption Summary

  • Purpose: Protect data confidentiality.
  • Process: Converts plaintext into ciphertext using an algorithm and a key.
  • Reversible? Yes ‚Äî with the correct key, you can decrypt the data back to its original form.
  • Use Case: Secure communication (e.g., HTTPS, emails, files).
    •  Example: AES Algorithm, RSA Algorithm , TLS.
    {/* */}
    {/* */}

    üßÆ 2. Encoding

  • Purpose: Make data readable by different systems or formats.
  • Process: Transforms data into a different format using a publicly known scheme.
  • Reversible? Yes ‚Äî anyone can decode it using the same scheme.
  • Use Case: Data transmission, storage (e.g., Base64, URL encoding).
    •  Example: Base64 (encoding turns binary data into ASCII text), UNICODE, ASCII, URL Encoding
    {/* */}
    {/* */}

    üî¢ 3. Hashing

  • Purpose: Verify data integrity or store data securely.
  • Process: Converts data into a fixed-size string (hash) using a hash function.
  • Reversible? No ‚Äî it's a one-way function.
  • Use Case: Password storage, file integrity checks, digital signatures.
    •  Example: SHA-256, MD5.
    ); }; export default O0_HashEncodeEncrypt;

import { MainChildArea } from "../../../../../components"; import { JavaHighlight, SpanBlue, SpanGreen, SpanRed } from "../../../../../components/Highlight"; import Li from "../../../../../components/ui/Li"; import ULdisc from "../../../../../components/ui/ULdisc"; const O1_IntroJwt = ({ anchor }: { anchor: string }) => { return (

üß© What is JWT?

JWT - Json Web Token

one of the best ways to secure ways to communicate between Client and Server.
The Advantage of Using JWT , because it completely follows stateless authentication mechanism.

üß© What Stateless Authentication Mechanism means?

Stateless Authentication Mechanism means , all the users input or user state, are{" "} never saved in server memory or cookies.

üß© Why JWT is considered stateless?

First, we set the session creation policy to STATELESS. (In a config class)
This does not disable session management in the underlying web server;
instead, it instructs Spring Security to no longer create or use an HTTP session for storing the authentication object.

  • A JWT itself carries all the information needed to identify the user (claims like sub, roles, exp, etc.).
  • After a client logs in and gets the token, the server does not need to keep session state in memory or in a database ‚Äî the token is self-contained and signed.
  • The server just needs the secret key (or public key, if asymmetric) to verify the signature.

    • This means any server instance can validate the token without coordinating with others ‚Üí stateless.

    üõë But then‚Ä¶ why do people still call the DB in filters?

    You might see code like this in a JWT filter:
    This feels stateful , but the DB lookup is not required for JWT authentication itself ‚Äî{" "} it‚Äôs just an implementation choice.

    Common reasons devs still load from DB:

  • To get fresh authorities/roles
    If the user‚Äôs roles/permissions can change while the token is still valid, checking against the DB ensures you‚Äôre always using the latest.
  • To validate user status
    For example: account disabled, deleted, or password changed since the token was issued.
  • To integrate with existing Spring Security UserDetailsService
    Sometimes it‚Äôs just reusing the standard way of building an Authentication object.

    • üß© Why disable CSRF if we use JWT?

    1. What CSRF protection is for?

  • CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) protection in Spring Security is mainly needed when your app uses stateful session-based authentication with cookies.
  • In that model, the browser automatically sends the session cookie with every request.
  • That means if a malicious site tricks the user‚Äôs browser into making a request to your app, the session cookie goes along for the ride ‚Üí possible CSRF attack.

    • 2. Why JWT is different?

  • With JWT-based authentication, we usually go stateless:
  • No server-side session.
  • The client (browser, mobile app, etc.) explicitly attaches the JWT (usually in the Authorization: Bearer {""}{" "} header).
  • Since the browser does not automatically attach the JWT like it does with cookies, an attacker cannot force the browser to ‚Äúaccidentally‚Äù send it.
  • This makes CSRF protection unnecessary in this scenario.

    • üß© The key point:

  • JWT itself is stateless.
  • After a client logs in and gets the token, the server does not need to keep session state in memory or in a database ‚Äî the token is self-contained and signed.
  • Your implementation can still add a DB call, which makes it feel "stateful," but that‚Äôs optional and not required for JWT to work.
  • If you want pure statelessness, you‚Äôd skip the DB call and fully trust the token claims (with proper expiration and signature validation).

    • ‚úÖ Rule of thumb:

  • If you want maximum scalability and statelessness ‚Üí trust the JWT fully.
  • If you need dynamic checks (role revocation, user disable, etc.) ‚Üí you‚Äôll end up querying DB or cache, which introduces a degree of ‚Äústatefulness‚Äù.

üß© What is the JSON Web Token structure?

See web site of JWT from{" - "}

In its compact form, JSON Web Tokens consist of three parts separated by dots (.), which are:

  • Header - xxxxx
  • Payload - yyyyy
  • Signature - zzzzz
    •  Therefore, a JWT typically looks like the following:
    {/* */}

    üß© Header

    The first part, the header typically consists of two parts:

  • the type of the token, which is JWT
  • and the signing algorithm being used, such as HMAC SHA256 or RSA.
    •

    Then, this JSON is Base64Url encoded to form the first part of the JWT.

    For example

    üß© Payload (Claim)

    The second part of the token is the payload, which contains the claims.

    Claims are statements about an entity (typically, the user) and additional data

    The Payload (Claim) helps us to answer: What do we want to store in JWT ?

    There are three types of claims:

  • Registered claims :
    These are a set of predefined claims which are not mandatory but recommended, to provide a set of useful, interoperable claims.
    Some of them are: iss (issuer), exp (expiration time), sub (subject), aud (audience), and others.
  • Public claims :
    These can be defined at will by those using JWTs. But to avoid collisions, they should be defined in the IANA JSON Web Token Registry or be defined as a URI that contains a collision-resistant namespace.
  • Private claims :
    These are the custom claims created to share information between parties that agree on using them and are neither registered or public claims.

    • The payload is then Base64Url encoded to form the second part of the JSON Web Token.

    An example payload could be:
  • iss (Issuer): who issues the JWT
  • iat (Issued at): time the JWT was issued at
  • exp (Expiration Time): JWT expiration time

    • üß© Signature

    The third part of the token is the signature. To create the signature part you have to take the encoded header, the encoded payload, a secret, the algorithm specified in the header, and sign that.

    For example, if you want to use the HMAC SHA256 algorithm, the signature will be created in the following way:

    The signature is used

  • to verify the message wasn't changed along the way,
  • and, in the case of tokens signed with a private key, it can also verify that the sender of the JWT is who it says it is.
    •

    The payload is then Base64Url encoded to form the second part of the JSON Web Token.

üß© JJWT (Java JWT Library)

JJWT (Java JWT Library) is built based on the full suite of JOSE (JavaScript Object Signing and Encryption) standards, including:
  • RFC 7519 ‚Äì JSON Web Token ( JWT )
  • RFC 7515 ‚Äì JSON Web Signature ( JWS )
  • RFC 7516 ‚Äì JSON Web Encryption ( JWE )
  • RFC 7517 ‚Äì JSON Web Key ( JWK )
  • RFC 7518 ‚Äì JSON Web Algorithms ( JWA )

    • üîß What You Can Do with JJWT:

  • Create signed JWTs (JWS) ‚Äî most common use case.
  • Create encrypted JWTs (JWE) ‚Äî for confidentiality.
  • Use custom headers, claims, and compression.
  • Support for various algorithms like RSA, AES, and more.
    •

üîë GitHub link
